value: Rosh Haniqra Cablecar, tunnel and restaurant
In the grottoes of Rosh Hanikra
Border crossing between Lebanon in Israel (closed to the public)

: ראש הנקרה "head of the rock caves"; also transliterated
) is a dazzlingly white coastal rock cliff formation on the far
. Rosh Hanikra is the northernmost point on the Mediterranean shore of Israel, the place where the chalk mountain ridge meets the sea essentially marking the (still hot!) border with

to the north. Despite its precarious location, visitors are safe (being mostly underground) and are rewarded by the sweet smelling limestone caverns and emerald-blue pools. The immediate coast is studded with inlets, lagoons and small beaches. On a clear day, the city of
can be seen to the south.

Buses 32 and 33 from go to the site, about 6 times a day. The trip is about 10km each way, so it may be affordable by taxi if several people are traveling.

To get to Nahariah, take the train from
The base of the cliffs at Rosh Haniqra can be accessed by a cablecar that operates throughout the year and is open daily 8.30am-5pm.

value: A chain of grottoes has been carved out by the power of the waves at the foot of the chalk cliffs - these beautiful grottoes are the main attraction of Rosh Hanikra.
During the Second World War the British dug a railway tunnel 250 meters long and built a bridge, as part of the Haifa - Beirut - Tripoli railway track.
